creator: sfhowes

content:
Returning to report that I solved this problem after discovering a post here: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1316689

As the user noted, "somehow" a VIEW setting for the SENT folder had changed. I'm suspicious of the change, too, as I hadn't fiddled with those settings...but Thunderbird had (with their new and very annoying Threaded default setting).

Solution: Highlight the SENT folder; select VIEW; under THREADS, check ALL. Done. All the messages instantly re-appeared.
creator: kakaako

content: Any chance of posting an image of the HTML of the sig? If it may help, send me a sample message to davidthunderbird at gmx dot com
creator: davidsk

content:
Well like I wrote, the images are local so normally it should work, but since TB seems to use deprecated html tags and especially doesn't allow "external" content to be loaded... I say deprecated because when you look in the html that TB generates there are tags that have been officially deprecated for a while, but TB continues to generate them...

I've seen a Lifewire article that showed how to add images in a signature in TB and so I've made a bogus message and added the content I needed with the links and saved that as an html file and used THAT file as my signature and now it works. It's just that my previous html5 signature file (which any relatively up to date browser can open just fine) was about 2kb in size, but the one I made in TB is around 23kb. That's because the images are written IN the html instead of being externally linked. Because of that care must be taken if there are alot of replies as this would potentially make for bigger and bigger messages being sent back and forth. It's not ideal, but it works.

I'm just surprised that this "solution" isn't mentioned more often in a bunch of other similar posts, it would save time and frustration. I would also suggest that TBird's html generator be updated to today's standards.

content: You could also be locked out of your account. Hotmail traditionally ignores any connection attempt in less that 15 minutes after the last. So if you change you connection frequency in account settings to check mail on less than a 15 minute cycle then you will be locked out until the timer for 15 minutes runs down.

creator: christ1

content:
I did try his solution. Take a look at my response and the accompanying illos. But I missed one important element:

It turns out that Flatpak has its OWN profile folders for TBird, separate from the profile folders living inside /home/stan/.thunderbird. The Flatpak profile containment folder is at /home/stan/.var/app/org.mozilla.Thunderbird/.thunderbird And the profiles in that folder DO contain msgFilterRules.dat files.

[ seems like it'd be good to somewhere document that profile folder location part of a Flatpak install ]

Help > Troubleshooting Information > Profile Directory, by the way, neither shows, nor opens, any Flatpak install profile folders.

Thus: now solved.

Thx everyone for assistance.

content:
Hi David.

All my Gmail Labels are fine and are all recreated faithfully as Folders in TB. This happened automatically by default without any need to specify a 'subscription'. This goes for Gmail System labels (Starred, Sent, Drafts etc.) as well as my custom ones.

Gmail Inbox Categories (Promotions, Updates etc.) are not the same thing and don't behave in the same way even in Gmail, hence my comments.
creator: Tolqua

content: I still do not understand what you are either requesting or suggesting. That is, are you experiencing a problem, or are you making a suggestion for a new feature?
creator: davidsk

content:
Gmail sorts incoming mail into Inbox Categories (Primary, Promotions, Social, Updates, Forums). These are not the same as Inbox Labels, which are applied separately to incoming mail.

This is convenient because as Tolqua mentioned, Gmail sorts items from "automated" sources (advertisements, lists, etc) into these Categories automatically, which leaves my Primary (inbox) relatively uncluttered and mostly populated with email from actual humans instead of ads.

The problem is that the use of Inbox Categories is not made available to external email clients such as Thunderbird, so that *all* of my incoming email is displayed in my Inbox. This makes it much harder to pick out the emails from family/friends/co-workers, in fact it makes Thunderbird almost unusable, for me anyway.

Tolqua (and I) are requesting that Google make the Categories functionality available to external email clients like Thunderbird, or perhaps another usable workaround.

content:
The point is Google do not offer the categories as folders in IMAP. See https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/#settings/labels The link will open in your own account to confirm that.

Nor do they offer them out as IMAP labels (The usual important work etc.)

So implementation will be rather problematic. I guess Thunderbird could try and reinvent the whole thing. But it can not be the same for obvious reasons in the land of the intellectual property.

I have heard discussions over the years of automatic identifiers and action buttons for mail. But fundamentally you are asking for Thunderbird to do something with information that is not available to it. So really I do not think the idea will fly.

"They've also not exposed this categorisation to the MAPI interface which is, I'm guessing, the main reason why the Inbox Categories are not supported in Thunderbird, right?"

I may have used the wrong acronym there, but as I then went on to say, another desktop client (Canary) does, indeed, support Inbox Categories. The filtration that Google uses to assign Inbox Categories is complex and, as you point out, proprietary, so Canary can only achieve this by accessing some identifier that replicates the categories faithfully in Canary (see screenshot). How it does this is not clear, but it does show it's possible - This is my point.

This topic has now been raised on the Ideas forum, so probably best to comment there: link to suggestion on Mozilla Ideas Forum

content:
I am not sure what you did. If you created a new profile, the possibility is that the old profile is still there. You can check for that by these steps: - help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open profile' - back up one level and you will be at ....appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles - this folder, Profiles, lists all profiles. Your old one and its contents may be there.

The other option is to exit thunderbird and use Windows FIle Explorer to view C:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles

content:
What is your anti-virus software?

Anti-virus software corrupting Thunderbird email files is most likely what happened. You can attempt to repair the index file for the troubled folder(s): Right-click the folder - Properties - Repair Folder

These are some generic suggestions to avoid problems with anti-virus software.

Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Don't let your anti-virus software scan incoming and outgoing messages.

Don't let your anti-virus software scan attachments.

Don't let your anti-virus software intercept your secure connection to the server.

Remove any add-ons your anti-virus software may have installed in Thunderbird.

Keep it working. http://kb.mozillazine.org/Keep_it_working_-_Thunderbird

And last but not least, backup your Thunderbird profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile

content:
In the end I backed up the profile and exported all emails as EML files from the Win 10 PC. I then

1. Uninstalled TB from the Win 11 PC 2. Deleted the TB profile data from the Win 11 PC 3. Reinstalled TB onto Win 11 PC 4. Copied the calendar local.sqlite in the calendar-data subdirectory from the Win 10 PC to the Win 11 PC 5. Copied the ID from the prefs.js on the Win 10 PC and edited prefs.js on the Win 11 PC, changing the 7 occurrences of the ID in prefs.js. See

https://ask.metafilter.com/353740/Help-me-import-a-previous-Thunderbird-calendar-into-a-new-profile

for a more detailed description.

2., 4. and 5. *must* be done while TB is not running.

I then restored the emails and address books (but nothing else) from the backed up profile of the Win 10 PC onto the Win 11 PC. The export and import of emails was a painful iterative operation since the exporting and importing of emails in 115.12.1 is buggy - only a (random?) subset of directories is correctly imported. Having EML files exported from the Win 10 PC allowed the manual recreation of subdirectories which were not exported/imported correctly.

Success! The Win 11 PC calendar now sends invites correctly.

It would be really good if the exporting and importing of TB data were functioning:

1. 115.12.1 TB calendar export/import is broken; see https://thunderbird.topicbox.com/groups/enterprise/T2c04aa4c32fb3256 as well as https://www.precedence.co.uk/wiki/Support-KB-Thunderbird/HomePage and https://forums.mozillazine.org/viewtopic.php?t=3110539 2. The email export/import transfers only random email subdirectories

and if the export/import functionality allowed selectable export of calendars, emails, address books and other data and not only an all-or-nothing lump.

Hola, Se puede cambiar el idioma de la intefaz del Thunderbird de forma similar que se hace en Firefox: Vas a Ajustes (Barra de Menú: Herramientas (tools)-> Ajustes (settings) o Botón de las 3 lineas a la izquierda de la barra del Thunderbird->Ajustes) ->General->Idioma (Language): En el menú desplegable revisa si esta el idioma Español de lo contrario se puede agregar presionando en el botón "Set Alternatives…" -> "Select a language to add" y buscas el español.

Otra alternativa mas facil es descargar el Thunderbird en Español desde: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/#S

Si se ha resuelto la consulta agradeceríamos marcar como solucionada para que sirva a otros usuarios.¡Gracias!

content: In terms of TB, this means Google accounts cannot be accessed with 'normal password' authentication, but must use OAuth2 authentication. This has been supported in TB for at least a couple of years. Check your gmail accounts in TB for the correct authentication method.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Messages with 1969 dates indicate missing Date headers so some sort of corruption is occuring.

Have you got any Anti-Virus which is allowed to scan your Profile folders? If yes, I would recommend that you do not allow anything to scan your profile folders and files because they have a habit of trying fix and causing no end of problems.

Corruption may also have occurred if you do not compact your folders meaning the mbox files storing emails may have more deleted or moved emails than current emails. The size of that file would also be a lot bigger than it's true contents.

As cause of corruption is perhaps unknown, I would recommend you move all your wanted emails out of the Inbox and store then in suitably named folders. Then when Inbox is empty. Right click on 'Inbox' and select 'compact' This should completely clean out that file so it's now ready for incoming mail.
